newsitem.title: GERMANY: German call money remains stable at 3.00 percent.
newsitem.headline: German call money remains stable at 3.00 percent.

text.p: German call money rates were mostly unchanged in midday dealings on Monday at about three percent, the same level as on Friday, traders said.
Traders said market liquidity appeared adequate as many players were believed to be ahead in their monthly reserve holdings and few expectations for troubles in meeting demands.
The Bundesbank on Monday announced a 15-day tender due to the month ending on a Wednesday -- the usual tender day -- and Thursday's national holiday.
About one billion marks was expected in the allocation on Tuesday after a 12-day tender for 59.9 billion marks expires.
"There shouldn't be much tension about the month-end reserve requirements," one trader said. "There may not even be Lombard borrowings."
The Bundesbank said on Monday that reserves as of Friday stood at 41.3 billion marks, about the same as Thursday's level at 41.4 billion marks.
The monthly average as of Sunday was unchanged at 41.1 billion marks, while Lombard borrowings were negligible.
